content: The first thing you should find out is if these kids will be considered YOUR dependents. Dependency can be defined for purposes of joining the service, and also for BAH. The definitions may be different for each case. I would ask in the recruiter forum. If they are your dependents for purposes of joining the service, the Navy might not even let you in. According to this Navy Legal Service Office website (scroll down near the bottom under "Military Support Regulations"): quote: The Navy, Air Force and Coast Guard do not have the authority to order their service members to pay support, including child support. The policies established by the Navy, Air Force and Coast Guard serve as guidelines for counseling service members. If the service member fails to respond positively to counseling and initiate support it can have a negative effect on his or her career. Failure to provide support can result in a loss of Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) for junior enlisted service members and the loss of the difference between BAH with dependents and BAH without dependents for senior enlisted and officers. Where the failure to provide support rises to the level that it brings discredit to the military service the service member may be punished. None of these actions results in the family member receiving support. There are also links on that website to each individual Service's specific regulations.
